## GAD-7 vs RCMAS

GAD-7 vs RCMAS When comparing the Generalised Anxiety Disorder Assessment (GAD-7) and the Revised Children's Manifest Anxiety Scale (RCMAS), researchers may face several challenges due to the manual and subjective nature of the process. But thanks to technology, comparing GAD-7 vs RCMAS just got easier with the Harmony software. Harmony software employs natural language processing and generative AI models to streamline the harmonisation of questionnaire items. With its database of instruments and a user-friendly interface, comparing GAD-7 vs RCMAS can be done with a few clicks. Researchers can either select from the available instruments or upload their own in PDF form. Harmony's unique feature is its multilingual capability. It not only effectively compares GAD-7 vs RCMAS but is capable of translating and analysing matches across languages. This makes it a powerful and efficient tool in the field of psychology and social research, saving valuable time and resources while ensuring a higher level of accuracy in results. Try Harmony for your GAD-7 vs RCMAS comparison and experience the ease and precision it offers.

## Compare the items in GAD-7 English and RCMAS

* <a href="https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app/#" target="harmonyapp">Import GAD-7 and RCMAS into Harmony and harmonise them</a> - find similarities between the two instruments using our AI platform
* <a href="https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app/#" target="harmonyapp">Import just GAD-7 into Harmony</a> - compare GAD-7 English with other instruments
* <a href="https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app/#" target="harmonyapp">Import just RCMAS into Harmony</a> - compare RCMAS with other instruments


## Questions in GAD-7

|   No. | GAD-7 English                                                                                                                                      |
|------:|:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|     1 | Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge                                                                                                               |
|     2 | Not being able to stop or control worrying                                                                                                         |
|     3 | Worrying too much about different things                                                                                                           |
|     4 | Trouble relaxing                                                                                                                                   |
|     5 | Being so restless that it is hard to sit still                                                                                                     |
|     6 | Becoming easily annoyed or irritable                                                                                                               |
|     7 | Feeling afraid, as if something awful might happen                                                                                                 |
|     8 | If you checked any problems, how difficult have they made it for you to do your work, take care of things at home, or get along with other people? |
